When G-rge our Pr-nce, first sway'd the land,</br>While yet Restriction cramp'd his hand,</br>Aspirants oft, with smiles and bows,</br>Throng'd the door of Carlton House,</br>Expecting, hinting, praying, striving,</br>To get the reigns, and shew their driving.</br>By turns they found the Princely mind</br>Disturb'd or calm, displeased or kind,</br>Till once, 'tis said, when one and all</br>Met impatient in his hall,</br>From a music-room beyond</br>They snatch'd the instruments of sound;</br>And, having heard, perhaps, at school,</br>How fiddling Orpheus rose to rule,</br>Each, for Madness ruled the hour,</br>Would tempt the self-same path to pow'r.
First fiddle Gr-nv-lle needs must try,—</br>And strain'd the chords, to make them sure:</br>Then back recoil'd, he knew not why,</br>From the unfinish'd overture.
Next, Br-gh-m came pushing from behind,</br>His native bagpipe at his side:</br>In one rude roar he forc'd the wind,</br>And sounded strong, and far, and wide.
The organ fell to B-r-n's share,</br>Low, sullen sounds his grief beguil'd:</br>A solemn, strange, and mingled air!</br>'Twas sad by fits, by starts 'twas wild.

But thou, O Cr-k-r, bard of flame,</br>What was thy prophetic story?</br>Still it spoke of promised glory,</br>And bade the lofty hopes at distance hail.</br>Still would his touch the strain prolong:</br>And from the fort, the height, the vale,</br>He call'd on W-ll-ngt-n through all the song;</br>And as that noble theme he chose,</br>Britain responsive cheer'd at every close,</br>And Cr-k-r  smil'd, well pleas'd, and Britain  boasts his fame,</br>And longer had he sung; but with a frown</br>Wh-thr-d impatient rose;</br>He threw his hat with boist'rous gesture down,</br>And, with a sulky look,</br>The lute of gentle Peace he took;</br>But swept a crash so loud and dread,</br>Were never sounds of war so full of woe!</br>And ever and anon he beat</br>A table near with furious heat:</br>And though sometimes, each breathless pause between,</br>C-stl-r-gh with courteous pride</br>His moderating voice applied,</br>Yet still he kept his bold unmanner'd mien,</br>While phrase of foul abuse seem'd brewing in his head.
The strains of M-ra's muse to nought were fix'd,—</br>A tremulous though ardent lay:</br>His theme was intermediarily mix'd,</br>And now he cheer'd the Prince, now grieving call'd on Gr-y.

With nose and chin that long'd to meet,</br>Pale St-nh-pe took his darkling seat:</br>And from that solitary place,</br>With measure long, and longer face,</br>Twang'd to the harpsichord his wiry drawl:</br>And jumbling there from jest-books old,</br>Quirks and quiddits quaintly roll'd.</br>Pert, yet unmark'd, the nasal numbers fall;</br>Or, after long and wearisome delay,</br>Ev'ry hearer's mind disposing</br>To a heavy mood of dozing,</br>In hollow murmurs die away.

But oh!  how alter'd was the livelier tone,</br>When W-ll-sley, with a soul of loftiest frame,</br>On whom expectant nations hung,</br>His eagle eye bright'ning in flame,</br>Blew an inspiring air, that Europe's confines rung,</br>The trumpet-blast, to Swede and Spaniard known!</br>High-born Castilians, gallant, yet serene,</br>Lusians and Catalans  were seen,</br>Leaving their groves of orange green;</br>Siberia's sons rejoiced to hear,</br>And Austria, waking, seized the vengeful spear.

Sh-r-d-n came at least to trial:</br>He, with viny crown advancing,</br>First to the lively pipe his hand address'd:</br>But soon he saw the soul-awak'ning viol,</br>Whose tone his nobler judgment love the best:</br>They would have thought, who heard the strain,</br>They mark'd Tyrtaeus breathing far</br>The patriot note of Grecian war,</br>To many a martial chorus dancing;</br>While, as his skilful fingers kiss'd the strings,</br>Wisdom and Mirth framed a harmonious round:</br>Then Wisdom gracious smil'd, with zone unbound,</br>And Mirth, amid his frolic play,</br>Beating brisk measure to the jocund lay,</br>Waved in the Sun his gaily burnish'd wings.

O Statesman, Poet, Scholar, Wit,</br>Pupil, and Friend, and Heir of Pitt,</br>Why, C-nn-ng, why, to us denied,</br>Lay'st thou thy wonted lyre aside?</br>As from great Chatham's son, of yore</br>Thou learn'dst an all-commanding pow'r,</br>Thy patriot soul, thine ardent strain,</br>Might bring those wish'd for days again.</br>Still be thy full and manly tone</br>True to the country and the throne;</br>Be still, as in all former time,</br>Warm, energetic, chaste, sublime;</br>Shine on this dark and fearful age,</br>And gild our hist'ry's deathless page.</br>'Tis said, and I believe the tale,</br>Thy slend'rest breath can more prevail,</br>Has more of strength and harmony—</br>Than all the Opposition's cry,</br>Although against thee jointly play</br>The bands of Gr-nv-lle and of Gr-y.</br>O bid their scattering forces fly:</br>Accord once more with Ministry:</br>Return to aid their skilful band,</br>And charm the discords of the land!</br>
